story: I lost  stone after my fiancé dumped me - now Ive finally found love againBushra Zafar-Khan, , felt completely lost when her fiancé broke up with her in , but when she made a change to her lestyle, she gained a new confidence that helped her find a new beauBushra finally found love after gaining confidence from her weight loss Image: PA Real LeByJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Oct | commentsA mum-of-one who was left heartbroken when her long-distance fiancé called it quits on their engagement has had the last laugh after shedding six stone and finding love again. Bushra Zafar-Khan, , was devastated when her beau, who lived in Pakistan, ended their long-distance betrothal - so much so that she decided to change her le. The mum-of-one, who lives in Canary Wharf, started her weight loss journey as a new yearaposs resolution in January  after realising her weight was st lb. She said: I was heartbroken when my engagement was called off because I was really looking forward to getting married, but it wasn’t meant to be. But after making changes to her le and watching the weight fall off her, Bushra had the confidence to open herself up to love again.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Five years on, sheaposs now married to her husband Fahad, , and they share three-year-old son, Salman. She said: “I thank my lucky stars that everything in le led me to where I am now - six stone lighter with a loving husband and a perfect little boy.” Bushra was introduced to her long-distance fiancé in  when she went to visit relatives in Pakistan. “I couldn’t wait to be married, so when he called off the engagement in December , I was devastated,” she said. She was  at the time and worried the clock was ticking for her.  Bushra added: I have polycystic oies, so I already thought it was probably too late for me to have children. I found the whole experience so depressing and, while deep down I knew the engagement hadn’t been called off because of my weight, I couldn’t help but feel low over it. I knew I wanted to make a change. A size  at the time, Bushra decided to search for weight loss support groups online and found advice from other women on how to sht the pounds. She said: It wasn’t necessarily how much I was eating, because I probably eat more now since the weight loss, but it was the type of foods I was eating. I was just having all the wrong things, like pizza, and at the wrong times. Although not hugely overweight, Bushra said her size was affecting how she felt about herself and spilled into her everyday le. She said: Even though I love sports, I couldnapost run as much because of my weight and lack of energy. Sometimes, when you’re bigger, you feel like certain things, such as failed relationships, are down to your weight. Even though it’s probably not that, it definitely knocks your confidence. In January , she discovered the DA Group after it was recommended by a friend. Bushra said: The DA Group offer dferent weight plans that you can follow, where they advise how much protein and vegetables to have in one sitting.  I started taking an energy supplement in the morning and following their suggestions at mealtimes. It’s quite flexible though, so I was still able to have a little treat in the day and, because you can have treats, there was nothing I was missing out on. They allow cheat days too which helped me with cravings. Within a month of following the new plan, Bushra said she lost more than a stone and dropped two dress sizes. A year later, she lost a whopping six stone, weighing in at st lb. It was incredible, I was wearing a size  which I never thought I would be. I felt so much more confident within myself. And with a new glow from the confidence sheaposd gained, Bushra even found love.  She said: I worked with Fahad at the university. I think he might have always fancied me but when we met, he knew I was engaged, so never pursued it. A few months after my engagement was called off, Fahad asked me out and I agreed to go for a coffee with him. I knew pretty early on that he was the one. The couple got engaged in July  and tied the knot just three months later. Bushra said: Everything happened really fast, even my pregnancy. I fell pregnant just two weeks after getting married. In July , Bushra welcomed little Salman into the world. All this time I was worried about my fertility, but I fell pregnant so quickly and naturally, she said. I think my weight loss played a role in that, but I also think it was just meant to be. Now Bushra is happier than ever with her new le - although she admits sheaposs still getting used to her figure. She said: It’s hard to believe sometimes that I’ve managed to lose so much weight and keep it off. I didn’t notice much of dference at first but people around me definitely did. It wasn’t until I started comparing photos that I realised how much weight I had lost. She now enjoys wearing stylish clothes, rather than hiding behind baggier fits. She notices the biggest change in herself when she goes on holiday and wears proper swimsuits.Have you had a body transformation  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcI look younger now that I did when I was in my s, she said. Other parents in the playground will chat to me while we wait for our children to come out of school, and they can’t believe it when I tell them that I’m . Half the time they think I’m joking, which is a bit of a confidence boost because I’ve come a long way to get to the point I’m at now. But my le is so much fuller now and I feel  years younger. story: Banksy’s amazing net worth, famous sightings and test that proves artists identityA shredded painting by the legendary street artist Banksy sold for a huge £million at auction last week - but who is really behind the mysterious moniker Hes the worlds most famous street artist - but who is Banksy  Image: Publicity PictureByAlex BellottiNews Features Writer:,  Oct | commentsIf you think modern art is rubbish, Banksy agrees.Last week, a shredded painting by the mysterious street artist named aposLove is in the Binapos sold for an enormous £million at auction - reaching £.million with fees.The famous piece was half sliced by a shredder concealed in its frame when it was sold at auction three years ago, drawing audible gasps from onlookers at Sothebyaposs in London. It was just the latest in a long line of stunts that has seen Banksy sneakily hang his works in the Tate and Louvre, and erect an inflatable Guantanamo Bay doll in Disneyland. Since rising to fame in the late s and early Noughties, the artistaposs witty, satirical murals and daring pranks have earned him millions of pounds. But what is his total fortune - and who is the man behind the mask  What is Banksyaposs net worth  Banksy began his career in the early s as part of the growing Bristol underground street art scene alongside artists like Nick Walker and Inkie. While his trademark stencil graffiti initially only popped up around the city, it later appeared in other locations like London and Brighton. Get the biggest news delivered to your inbox.for the Mirroraposs free newslettersIn , he put on his first gallery exhibition in Los Angeles, and since then his pieces have skyrocketed in popularity and value.His net worth is said to be million , according to Celebrity Net Worth - though he prefers any proceeds from sales to go to charity.Instead, Banksyaposs income is said to come from sales of books and films about his work. In , he published a best-selling tome, Wall and Piece, while he also directed a documentary called Exit Through The Gt Shop. The film - about a young artist who goes looking for Banksy - was even nominated for an Oscar and raked in £million.  Despite his success, however, the aposguerrillaapos artist has always preferred being a counter-culture hero. Graffiti art has a hard enough le as it is, before you add hedge-fund managers wanting to chop it out and hang it over the fireplace, he told Village Voice. For the sake of keeping all street art where it belongs, I’d encourage people not to buy anything by anybody, unless it was created for sale in the first place. Prime suspects - from music legend to Art Attack star Over the years, Banksyaposs true identity has been a source of frenzied speculation - and some of it is truly bizarre. Fans of the hit s TV series Art Attack may recall that last year former host Neil Buchanan was forced to deny he was the masked menace.  After a rumour circulated that Banksy artwork had appeared in locations close to where the -year-oldaposs former band Marseille had played gigs, his website issued a statement shutting down the theories. Neil Buchanan ISNaposT Banksy, it read. We have been inundated with enquiries over the weekend regarding the current social media story. Unfortunately this website does not have the infrastructure to answer all these enquiries inidually, however we can confirm that there is no truth in the rumour whatsoever. One of the more persistent rumours links Banksy with Massive Attack musician Robert Del Naja, also known as D. Before his rise with the iconic Bristol trip hop band, Del Naja was considered to be the cityaposs first graffiti artist and a pioneer of the stencil art movement. In what could be a cunning double bluff, heaposs been praised by Banksy as an early influence and the pair are said to be friends. However, fans were left convinced they could be one and the same after singer Goldie aposlet slipapos Robaposs name while mentioning Banksy in a  podcast interview. He said: Give me a bubble letter and put it on a T-shirt and write aposBanksyapos on it and weaposre sorted, we can sell it now. No disrespect to Rob, I think heaposs a brilliant artist. I think he has flipped the world of art over. One theory put forward by Scottish journalist Craig Williams is that Banksy could in fact be a collective of artists - although he suggested it could be headed up by Del Naja. He wrote: A multi disciplined artist in front of one of the seminal groups in recent British history, doubling up as the planetaposs most revered street artist. Now that would be cool.  The most popular theory, however, is that Banksy is the lesser known artist Robin Gunningham. In , a photograph emerged of a man in Jamaica with a spray can at his feet that was said to show the artist at work. A Mail On Sunday article claimed to have identied the man as former public schoolboy Gunningham after talking to his childhood pals in Bristol. The theory took off further in  when Banksyaposs lawyers tried to delay the publication of a report by researchers from Queen Mary University which used aposgeographic profilingapos to unmask him. The technique - often used to catch serial criminals - analysed the locations of  artworks to seethere were any common links with the main apossuspectsapos.“I’d be surprisedit’s not [Gunningham]” Steve Le Comber, a biologist and co-author of the study, told the BBC. “It rapidly became apparent that there is only one serious suspect, and everyone knows who it is. Mysterious apossightingsapos of legendary artist While heaposs impressively avoided the limelight for decades, a few apossightingsapos of Banksy have been reported over the years. In , a man in a hi-vis jacket was snapped spraying the White Horse pub in Liverpool.  Taken years after the painting had been confirmed as authentic, itaposs believed to be the first picture of the artist at work - but his face is frustratingly hard to make out. Then in , a graffiti artist in Australia was caught on video spraying a wall in Melbourne, Australia - signing it off as Banksy. The woman behind the camera chases down the man as he hurries away, causing him to turn around and yell f*** off before fleeing. However, the artwork didnapost quite look Banksyaposs usual style - and his team later insisted it was a fake. Shortly afterwards, footage emerged of a man spraying an underpass in Briston for a Sunday Times Magazine piece on the artist. The shaky footage shows an artists arriving on a bike to paint the wall before taking off, though itaposs thought he could also be a member of the iconaposs team.  Earlier this summer, Banksy filmed himself in the act, taking to Instagram to claim credit for new spectacular street murals which had been discovered in Suffolk and Norfolk.The mystery artist uploaded a video of himself getting down to work at locations after driving a campervan packed full of spray paint. title: call schoolkids use walk jab
story: Call for schoolkids to use walk-in jab centres as just % vaccinated in some areasIt remains crucial that the in-school programme is rolled out as quickly as possible but only  councils have vaccinated at least a quarter of  to -year-oldsGetting the jab at at a pop-up vaccination centre during a four-day vaccine festival in Langdon Park in east LondonImage: PAByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsUnions are calling for school-age teens to be allowed to use walk-in vaccination centres as in some areas a few as % are jabbed. Take up in England is below % in just over a third of the main local authorities and only  councils have vaccinated at least a quarter of  to -year-olds. By contrast in Scotland - where children can use walk-in centres - take-up is already over % in half of local authority areas. James Bowen, policy director at school leaders’ union NAHT, said: “It remains crucial that the in-school programme is rolled out as quickly as possible. “We know that the health teams working in schools are working tirelessly to achieve this, but they need full support from the Government. “Those who want to get the vaccination should be able to do so as quickly as possible. “Allowing - year olds to attend walk-in vaccination centres would be a sensible decision.” Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section  Three million pupils aged between  and  across the UK are eligible to receive a first dose of the Covid- vaccine as part of a rollout that began a month ago. In England, jabs are being carried out in schools by nurses and immunisation teams. In Scotland doses can be received by attending drop-in vaccination centres at GP clinics, pharmacies and community centres. Around one in  children in England in school years seven to  were likely to have tested positive for Covid- in the week to October  - the highest rate for any age group - according to the Office for National Statistics.  Get the latest news you want direct to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders , said: “We are hearing reports from around the country of very ied delivery of the Covid- vaccine to  to -year-olds in schools and signicant delays to the vaccination programme, which the Government had originally hoped to complete by half-term. “Schools have reported logistical problems such as the vaccination teams having insufficient staff to deal with the number of students needing jabs, running out of vaccines or even not turning up when they have arranged to. “The Government needs to do everything possible to boost the delivery and take-up of the vaccination.” The Prime Minister’s official spokesman said: “There are a number of dferent factors, there’s no one single issue that presents a challenge. “As ever with Covid there are a number of challenges to overcome.” Another potential Covid- vaccine has recorded positive trial results but it comes after Britain cancelled its order for doses. Pharmaceutical firm Valneva had set up a manufacturing plant in Livingstone, Scotland, and announced its jab showed stronger antibody responses than the AstraZeneca jab. It is hoped the vaccine will trigger a stronger T-cell response that is a more robust defence against new iants. The phase three trial had recruited , people across  trial sites in the UK. Lead trial investigator Prof Adam Finn, of Bristol University, who also sits on the JCVI, said: “The low levels of reactogenicity and high al antibody responses alongside broad T-cell responses seen with this adjuvanted inactivated whole virus vaccine are both impressive and extremely encouraging. “This is a much more traditional approach to vaccine manufacture than the vaccines so far deployed in the UK, Europe and North America and these results suggest this vaccine candidate is on track to play an important role in overcoming the pandemic.”The UK deal with the French company for  million doses was scrapped last month as Health Secretary Sajid Javid told MPs it had been “clear” the vaccine “would not get approval” here.Prof Finn said Mr Javid’s comments had been “corrected in Hansard” and suggested they were incorrect. Valneva’s chief medical officer Dr Juan Carlos Jaramillo told a briefing they expected to get UK approval around the turn of the year. title: cruel woman stuffed naughty kitten
story: Cruel woman stuffed naughty kitten in washing machine and put it on full cycleWARNING GRAPHIC IMAGES: Morritz, a -week-old black and white kitten, died after being stuffed inside a washing machine after it pooed in the house of Catherine Young, Catherine Young has been disqualied indefinitely from keeping all animals after she put her -week-old kitten Morritz in a washing machine Image: RSPCAByKate Buck:,  Oct | commentsA cruel woman who killed her -week-old kitten by putting in a washing machine on a full cycle has been banned from keeping animals indefinitely. Catherine Young, , put the defenceless black and white kitten, called Morritz, in the machine as a punishment for pooing inside her home in Clacton, Essex. She smeared the kittenaposs face in its own faeces before going through with her cruel act. Young, , admitted to two animal welfare offences following a prosecution by the RSPCA. Colchester Magistratesapos Court heard -week-old black and white kitten Morritz died after being put on a full cycle as a punishment for going to the toilet in the house. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter She has now been disqualied indefinitely from keeping all animals. The court heard how the RSPCA was contacted after Young rang a veterinary practice on June  to say one of her kittens had died at home. When she eventually arrived at the practice later that evening, she had with her one live male kitten called Bobbitz, and a dead kitten called Morritz, who was cold and stf with wet fur. The court heard that when questioned about what had happened by a veterinary surgeon at the practice, Young admitted she had put Morritz in the washing machine because she had been naughty and defecated in the house. She said she had rubbed the kittenaposs face in the faeces to tell her off before putting her in the washing machine on a short cycle to clean her fur. She said she had done this before and Morritz had been fine.  Young also admitted to the vet that she had withheld food and water from both kittens in the past for at least  hours because they had been naughty. Bobbitz, a semi long haired black and white kitten, was examined and found to be clinically well. Young was told that he would stay at the practice to be looked after and she would be unable to have him back. RSPCA inspector Jessica Dayes, who investigated the case, interviewed Young on June . No other animals were seen at the address, however empty litter trays, cat litter, a broken cat carrier and a bag of cat food were still in the kitchen, she said. In his witness statement to the court, the vet said: It is my opinion that the deceased kitten had undergone signicant unnecessary suffering by being deliberately placed in a washing machine and then this being placed on a wash cycle. The spinning of the machine and the water would have caused signicant pain, injury and huge amounts of stress. Young, who represented herself, said she had a personality disorder and mental health issues. She was also fined £ and ordered to pay £ in costs and a £ victim surcharge. Bobbitz has been renamed Gulliver and is doing well in a new home. story: EasyJet charged couple £ to change name on ticket after simple booking mistakeThe hefty cost was incurred after a straight forward error was made on the original bookings for flights from Inverness to Bath but the airline has since apologised. EasyJet is a British and European low cost airline, a budget carrier and easyjet Switzerland that connects Athens to Berlin Tegel, Bristol, Edinburgh, London Gatwick, Manchester, Naples, Basel   Mulhouse and seasonal to: Berlin Schönefeld, Milan Malpensa, Paris Orly and Geneva. The airlines has its headquarters at London Luton Airport and has a fleet of  airplanes with  destinations served. " content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _EasyJet-Airbus-A.jpg" width"" "" A simple error when booking the tickets meant the couple had to £ - more than the cost of the two originalflights Image: NurPhoto via Getty ImagesByKieren Williams:,  Oct | commentsEasyJet charged a couple £ just to change the name on one of their tickets.The airline company told the husband, who was flying from Inverness to Bath, to buy completely new tickets for his we after he accidentally booked all their flights in his own name.His simple error when buying the £flights meant their boarding passes only showed his name,The report.He asked staff to change one of the seats to his we’s name but was stunned when he was told he would have to splash £ for entirely new tickets for her. Staff initially refused to budge and the couple shelled out. However, when they landed in Bath, an EasyJet employee told them they should only have been charged for the name change, not made to buy entirely new tickets. When they complained to EasyJet the couple were initially offered a measly £, theof air passenger duty on the unused tickets, compared to the £ they spent on top of their original tickets.An EasyJet spokesperson said: “ When genuine spelling errors are made, we will use discretion to recty them without a customer incurring any fees before they fly.Customers should inform us when errors have been made during the booking process and it is passengers’ responsibility to check their ticket documentation is correct. “On this occasion the customer had unfortunately booked all flights in their own name, which was identied at security. We are sorry that the customer was incorrectly advised of their options at the airport and so we provided them with a refund for the cost of their original seat selection, as well as for the dference in cost of the name change fee and their new flight.  “The safety and security of our customers is our highest priority and airlines must ensure that the passenger flying is the person stated on the ticket.This is not the first time fliers have had issues with EasyJet in recent weeks,one family from Bristol saw their holiday ruinedafter the company removed their luggage and pram from a plane.Irene Garcia Santos, her husband Leigh Husband and their toddler Antonio had travelled to Lisbon for a wedding. EasyJet said the couple had been “denied boarding” and never let on the plane, despite having flown and landed in Portugal, so taken their luggage off the flight. title: elderly man 89 broken leg
story: Elderly man, , with broken leg forced to wait seven hours for ambulance to arriveHarry Soar, , from Heanor, Derbyshire, fell at his home and had to wait for seven hours in excruciating pain with a broken leg for an ambulance to arrive at his homeHarry Soar, , fell at his home and had to wait for seven hours for an ambulance Image: Ann Hudson   BPM MediaByFaith PingTim Hanlon:,  Oct | commentsThe daughter of an -year-old man has told how he was forced to wait seven hours in excruciating pain with a broken leg for an ambulance to arrive at his home.Harry Soar fell at his home and was unable to move due to the pain he was in, on Sunday, October , reported DerbyshireLive.Instead he called his son and daughter, who live nearby to Heanor, Derbyshire, and they found their father on the floor. Harry’s daughter Ann Hudson, , immediately called for an ambulance at .pm. She said: “We rushed down to his house, me and my brother, and he was lying on the floor.  “We managed to get him up and into a chair, but he was in a lot of pain, so I rang  as you do, because I thought I can’t move him, not really, because he was in too much pain to be moved. “When I rang  they said it could be a while, so I rang back a number of times, at least twice to get an update. “A clinician did ring and went through a number of questions but it was seven hours before they actually turned up to pick him up, and it turns out he’d broken his thigh bone.” Despite the agonising seven-hour wait for an ambulance, his daughter said that Mr Soar blames government cuts to health services rather than the NHS or East Midlands Ambulance Service. Further delaying treatment was the fact that Mr Soar had to be taken to Queenaposs Medical Centre, in Nottingham, as the Royal Derby Hospital did not have the capacity to treat him, added his daughter Ann. Due to the non-le-threatening nature of Harry’s fall, his request for an ambulance was logged as a category  call - one which is potentially serious and requires possible pain control and treatment. But category  calls are not immediately le-threatening and therefore are not a priority to the ambulance service. Nationally, the ambulance service aims to respond to these calls within an average time of  minutes, and nine times out of ten within two hours. Instead, Mr Soar had to wait in his home in pain for seven hours. His daughter continued: “They said it could be up to six hours, but we were hoping for less than that. “When it came to six hours time and they hadn’t turned up, I rang them back and they said it could be six or more hours. “They weren’t friendly on the phone I would say, they were just very busy. “I just don’t think it’s right, especially with an -year-old being left that long in pain. “On the day I was very angry because obviously your parents are your responsibility basically, and you’ve got to look after them when they get older.” Mr Soar was eventually seen by the ambulance crew and taken to Nottingham’s Queen’s Medical Centre, after being told that Royal Derby hospital was closed to emergencies because they were too busy. Despite their long wait, Harry and his family understand that the delay was a result of high demand for NHS services. Ann said: Despite waiting seven hours for an ambulance, he doesnapost blame them, he blames the government cuts for the delay. After breaking his thigh bone during the fall, Mr Soar has since had an operation to help his mobility. Craig Whyles, service delivery manager for Derbyshire at East Midlands Ambulance Service, said: “We are very sorry to hear that we were unable to get to Mr Soar sooner on this occasion and I recognise the distress that this will have caused to him and his family. “Every  call is assessed based on the information provided by the caller and people experiencing a le-threatening emergency such as cardiac arrest or breathing dficulties have to be seen first. “Using the information shared during the initial call, this incident was categorised as not immediately le-threatening. “At the time there was a high demand on EMAS and the wider NHS system, and we were responding to a number of people whose le was reported to be at immediate risk. “We are currently in contact with Mr Soar and his family through our Patient Advice and Liaison Service and will fully investigate the reason for this delay.” Comment MORE ON NHSHospitals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. But when it comes to choosing baby names in the UK, it seems many parents tend to think alike - with several favourite names seeming to top the charts every year. Names like Amelia and Isla often top the list of girlsapos names, with Jack and James always being firm favourites for newborn boys.  And the top choice for both girls and boys remains unchanged this year - with Olivia and Oliver taking first preference among parents in England and Wales for the eighth year in a row. story: Mum, , accused of neglect for leaving five-week-old baby with her gran overnightZoe Wallace, , typically shares TikTok videos to her thousands of followers as a busy mum-of-two but in a recent one she received an avalanche of online abuse about her youngest child Parker having a sleepover with her granZoe Wallace was criticised on TikTok after sharing how her youngest daughter Parker spent the night at her grans when she was five weeks old Image: Manchester Evening NewsByEmma GillAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsA mum has been accused of neglect after leaving her five-week-old baby with a grandparent overnight.Zoe Wallace, , typically shares TikTok videos to her thousands of followers documenting her le as a busy mum with two kids. Her recent video hit more than seven million views and resulted in her receiving horric abuse online,Manchester Evening News reports. The mum, from Wigan, told her followers about her daughter Parker falling ill RSV - or respiratory syncytial virus - when she was five weeks old. RSV is a viral illness that causes symptoms such as breathing problems and can lead to more severe bronchiolitis and pneumonia in young babies. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter She describes how Parker, who is now four months old, had to be moved from AE to a high dependency unit where she was put on a machine to do the breathing for her. The youngster was diagnosed with a severe chest infection but thankfully began to recover with the help of antibiotics. In the video, she had also said Parker spent the night with her gran - who lives a -minute drive away, before falling ill.  Many TikTok users blasted the mum for letting Parker have her first sleepover with her gran the night before she fell ill. One wrote: Jesus, five weeks and you are done with it already  Poor child isnapost gonna grow up the best. Another said: This is neglect. How could you do that to your newborn. Zoe has shared her own video hitting back at the comments. She told MEN: I posted the video originally to share my daughter’s story with RSV.  It made her very poorly and I was unaware how serious it could be in newborns. I hadn’t even heard about it until she was poorly and I wanted to make other mums aware of the signs. I had mentioned that she stayed with my mum the night before falling ill to show how quickly she declined but it wasn’t taken that way. People in the comments have branded me a bad mum because of my decision to allow my mum to have my child overnight.  To me, personally, it’s pretty normal for new mums to get support in anyway from family members but I didn’t know it would be so controversial online. I do regret mentioning her staying at my mumaposs because of the hate I have received, but I don’t regret sharing my daughteraposs story, because it could help save another child’s le. Zoe, who also has a three-year-old son Dominic with partner David Hunt, , also spoke about some of the disgusting comments she received. She said: The most hurtful is that I’m neglecting my children, I’m a bad parent, that my daughter deserved to die because she wouldn’t have bad parents. That I don’t deserve children or I shouldn’t have childrenI’m too lazy to look after them. The main hate I received was along the lines of aposhow could you leave your babyapos  It just shocked me how it’s encouraged as a new mum to accept help from people you trust because it can be overwhelming, but as soon as you do it’s seen as neglectful. I think the video going viral has proven the double standards for mums, there’s a lot of mum shaming and I don’t think it’s fair. Zoe, who is on maternity leave from her job at McDonaldaposs, said sheaposs been more willing to accept help from her mum with Parker as she was reluctant with Dominic despite suffering from postnatal depression. Zoe first started posting videos to TikTok during the lockdown and now has more than , followers. She said: I will carry on with it because at the end of the day itaposs my choice ultimately - my kids are fine and my kids are happy. They love spending time with my mum and what other people think is not going to change that, or change what Iaposm posting either. I have people who follow me and they chat to me daily and say they like seeing the content so I wonapost let this stop me. news uk-news mum-left-looking-like-sloth-"Woman has allergic reaction after getting eyebrows tintedByHelen Le CaplainRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA mum thought she aposlooked like Sloth from The Gooniesapos after suffering a horror reaction to an eyebrow tint. Shocking photos show how Emily Priceaposs face ballooned and her her forehead aposcurled overapos into her eyes after applying the popular beauty treatment. Emily, , from Merthyr Tydfil, South Wales, said she was left with red and crusty-looking brows after a trip to the salon on September . The mum-of-one thought she wouldnapost need a patch test as she previously used the product routinely - though hadnapost since the pandemic outbreak. She was initially happy with the results, but claims her eyebrows started to tingle an hour after having them done and it felt like a aposhot pokerapos on her skin. But when Emily awoke unable to open her eyes properly she became concerned. She was horried when her startled husband leapt out of bed clutching a mirror so she could see her swollen, weeping face. Emily rang her GPaposs surgery but was forced to simply describe her symptoms over the phone as she couldnapost get a face-to-face appointment due to Covid. With her face continuing to balloon over the coming days, Emily went to AE where stunned staff prescribed her with powerful antibiotics to tackle the infection. Emily fears her new allergic reaction could be a result of having had the Covid vaccine, after reading about links made between people having had Covid or having the vaccine and experiencing new allergies, however there is nothing to prove that. And Emily, who is double-jabbed with the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine, still remains a staunch advocate of getting the vaccine.  Emily, whoaposs never experienced allergic reactions in the past, watched in horror as her scabby eyebrows dropped off in patches - forcing her to colour them in with an eyebrow pencil. Now healed, writer Emily is now speaking out about her ordeal to ensure no-one goes through what she has and is urging people to always carry out patch tests, eventhey have previously not had an allergy.Whether youaposre an actual mummy or just the sort made of bandages, Halloween will be a big deal in your house. I thought maybe she left a little bit on so I gave my face a wash thinking it would get rid of any excess.  As the hours went on it started to feel like when you burn yourself on a hot pan and you pull your hand away quickly. It was like that but it was asI couldnapost pull away from it, it was just burning hot like there was a poker across my eyebrows. I went to sleep and when I woke up there was a moment of panic as I couldnapost open my eyes properly, they were just slits. My husband was next to me, he turned the light on and looked at me and he was like aposoh my god whataposs happened to your face apos.  He ran and got a mirror, I could barely even see myself because my eyes were so swollen and I noticed that close, underneath the eyebrows, it had gone yellow. Days later I ended up going into hospital because it got worse. I looked like Sloth from The Goonies. An hour after having the beauty treatment Emily started to experience a tingling sensation and the following day she woke up to discover her face had ballooned. Worried at how it would develop, Emily managed to get a GP appointment over the phone on September th and was prescribed face wash, antihistamines and a steroid cream. But the medications did not help, and Emily took herself to Prince Charles Hospitalaposs AE department in Merthyr Tydfil on September  and was seen quickly by a skin specialist who started her on a strong course of antibiotics. She took a week-long course of antibiotics that cleared her skin but was horried when patches of eyebrow hair dropped out. Emily is sharing her experience to urge people to always get patch tested - claiming that although itaposs a apospainapos itaposs not worth being left aposlooking like a car crashapos. news uk-news pip-claimants-could-entitled--"Changes confirmed for applying for PIP, ESA and Universal CreditByPatrick ODonnellAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsPIP claimants could be entitled to £, after a Department for Work and Pensions rule change.At the start of the coronavirus pandemic, the DWP previously announced plans to change the process of how people apply for PIP. This affected the amount of financial support claimants were given by the DWP during certain time frames, SussexLive reports. The department altered the definition of social support in April , which led to many claimants seeing a change in their benefits payments. PIP is awarded to claimants who need additional financial assistance to pay for the living costs associated with a long-term physical or mental disability. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Payments are then handed out in two separate parts which are a daily living component and a mobility component. The daily living component has two dferent weekly rates, which is either a lower rate of £ and a higher one of £.. In regards, to the mobility component, it is either a lower rate of £. and a higher rate of £.. Usually, when someone begins their PIP application, they are assessed on their ability to interact with other people face-to-face. The rule change affects current PIP claimants, people who applied for PIP in the past but do not get it today and people moving from Disability Living Allowance . However, according to the DWP,a claimant needs “prompting” or reminded from a trained inidual in social situations, the department would now consider whether this comes under social support. The DWP stated: “The change also claries that social support is an ongoing need to help engage with other people. It does not need to be during or immediately before the activity.”  Following this, the DWP is looking to find current and past claimants who were affected by this change dating back to April . Specically, the DWP said: “This includes looking again at some claims we decided on or after April , , where PIP was awarded because of needing ‘prompting’ to engage with other people face to face. “We will now consider whether they need ‘social support’. This includes some claims where we did not award PIP.” However, the department claried that it will not be looking at claims which saw the enhanced rate of the daily living part of PIP being awarded continuously since April . Furthermore, the DWP will not reexamine a claima Tribunal has already made a decision or decision was made to not award PIP before April . In terms of eligibility, the DWP explained: “Not everyone will be eligible. If you are, we will write to you and you do not need to contact us. “It may take some time for you to get this letter. We are not planning to invite you for an assessment as part of this review, but we may contact you for more information. “If we decide that you should get more PIP, then your award will usually be backdated to  April . “If you claimed PIP after April , , it will usually be backdated to the date you started getting PIP.” All Britons who think they are eligible for PIP are encouraged to apply, with the rule changes now being factored into all future claims. People looking to apply for PIP can contact their local DWP centre or begin their application online. title: prince charles plans to slim
story: Prince Charles plans to slim down monarchy and open Buckingham Palace to publicIn years to come it is likely we will see fewer royals around and a recalibration of what it means to be a working member of the royal familyAccording to reports, Prince Charles is likely to trim down the core royal family Image: PAByMirror:,  Oct | commentsPrince Charles will trim down the monarchy to get rid of hangers-on while Buckingham Palace could be opened up to the public when he takes the throne, reports say. It has long been said that Charles plans a major shake-up of the Royal Family when he becomes head of state - and it could also affect royal residences.In a bid to slim down the royal estate when he ascends to the throne, it has been reported that he will live in little more than “ a flat above the shop” at Buckingham Palace and use Highgrove as his family home. It is also understood that Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge will move from Kensington Palace to Windsor Castle, a relocation that the couple is said to want.It is likely we will see fewer royals around and a recalibration of what it means to be a working royal when Prince Charles steps up to the helm.In the latest episode of The ’s Royal Insight, Camilla Tominey has outlined the major changes expected to happen within the royal family and explained why the incoming monarch is expected to drive the new direction.Thereaposs this sense that he wants a slimmed down monarchy to make sure that everybody is doing their bit and [there are] no so-called hangers-on. Tominey said in the past there had been some negative publicity surrounding the more minor royals seemingly living in family accommodation and seemingly not doing much. “So I think this is basically Charles’ attempt to basically look like he’s inherited his mother’s habit for being frugal turning off light switches and being green, generally being good value for money, she explained. The death of the Queen, Tominey said, was going to cause a “seismic shock” for the British public and would necessitate an “enormous adjustment” from everybody. “Therefore I think there’s a sense of trying to make that as smooth as possible and trying to create a monarchy that’s fit for the future.”  With the slimming down of the royal family that we’ve seen so far, Tominey said, had come the need to ‘recalibrate’ what it means to be a royal.Back in Prince Philip ’s day, royal duties largely revolved around the charities and other organisations the prince was a patron for planting a tree or unveiling a plaque at an event.But younger royals like Kate and William had been forging a new path on which they were launching their own initiatives or projects centered around causes they were passionate about, driven by work online or podcasts. “That means by association that you’re going to have fewer royals taking on fewer patronages, and then what does that mean for the charities ” Tominey questioned. She pointed out that the departure of the Sussexes, Prince Andrew and Prince Philip from royal le meant that even now, there were “too few royals to go around’ comparatively to what the public were used to. And while she expected there would be a ‘stepping up’ of Charles and Camilla alongside the other royals, to take on these duties, Tominey said there may be too much work to go around.  The royal expert also said that a slimming down of the royal family might put some noses out of joint at the Queen’s Diamond Jubilee the omission of all but seven royals from the balcony at Buckingham palace was said to have upset others who were not included. Moving forward, Tominey said, the Cambridges appeared to be trying to normalise the lives of their children, potentially paving the way for Charlotte and Louis to have their own careers outside of their royal lives. “It does make the future of the monarchy kind of uncertain,” she said. “We’ve had this model that the Queen has been at the head of for all of this time, because she’s obviously been on the throne for nearly seven decades.” But the next decade would see everything change, she said. Another major change that had been rumoured was the opening of Buckingham Palace to the public - an idea that Tominey thought likely to have been briefed in order to “exacerbate Prince Charles’ value-for-money credentials. title: wake up 3am cant stop
story: Why we wake up at am and cant stop worrying - yet by morning the fear has goneGreg Murray, a psychology researcher, and an expert in mood and sleeping explains why peoples worries are so much greater in the middle of the night than during the dayGreg Murray, a psychology researcher, explains why people worry more at night Image: Shared Content UnitByLiv ClarkeDaniel SmithTim Hanlon:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWaking up in the middle of the night and having a panic attack about an event that by the morning suddenly seems unimportant is something we all do but why  We’ve all had one of those nights, where you wake up at around am and your mind slips into a spiral of negative thoughts.All your worries suddenly take on more importance in the middle of the night, leaving you worried and fretful and unable to get back to sleep, HullLive reports.Yet during the day these concerns no longer seem that serious - turns out you lost sleep over nothing. So, what’s going on  Greg Murray, a psychology researcher with expertise in mood, sleep and the circadian system , has explained why this happens.  Professor Murray says: “In a normal night’s sleep, our neurobiology reaches a turning point around  or am. “Core body temperature starts to rise, sleep drive is reducing , secretion of melatoninhas peaked, and levels of cortisolare increasing as the body prepares to launch us into the day.“Remarkably, all this activity happens independent of cues from the environment such as dawn light – nature decided long ago that sunrise and sunset are so important that they must be predicted .“We actually wake up many times each night, and light sleep is more common in the second half of the night. When sleep is going well for us, we are simply unaware of these awakenings. But add a bit of stress and there is a good chance that waking will become a fully self-aware state. “Not surprisingly, there is evidence the pandemic is a sleep-disturbing stressor. Soyou’re experiencing am wakings at the moment, you’re definitely not alone. “Stress also impacts sleep in insomnia, where people become hypervigilant about being awake. “Concerns about being awake when one “should” be asleep can cause the person to jolt themselves into anxious wakefulness whenever they go through a light sleep phase.  “If that sounds like you, be aware that insomnia responds well to psychological treatment with cognitive behavioural therapy. There’s also a strong link between sleep and depression, so it’s important to speak to your doctoryou have any concerns about your sleep.” “As a cognitive therapist, I sometimes joke the only thing good about am waking is that it gives us all a vivid example of catastrophising,” Professor Murray says. “Around this time in the sleep cycle, we’re at our lowest ebb physically and cognitively. From nature’s viewpoint, this is meant to be a time of physical and emotional recovery, so it’s understandable that our internal resources are low. “But we also lack other resources in the middle of the night – social connections, cultural assets, all the coping skills of an adult are unavailable at this time. With none of our human skills and capital, we are left alone in the dark with our thoughts. So the mind is partly right when it concludes the problems it’s generated are unsolvable – at am, most problems literally would be. “Once the sun’s up, we’re listening to the radio, chewing our Vegemite toast and pushing the cat off the bench, and our am problems are put in perspective. We can’t believe the solution of just ringing this person, postponing that thing, or checking such-and-such was overlooked in the wee hours.“The truth is, our mind isn’t really looking for a solution at am. We might think we are problem solving by mentally working over issues at this hour, but this isn’t really problem solving it’s problem solving’s evil twin – worry.“Worry is identying a problem, ruminating about the worst possible outcome and neglecting the resources we would bring to bear should the non-preferred outcome actually occur.” Professor Murray adds: “Have you noticed the am thoughts are very self-focused  In the quiet dark, it’s easy to slide unknowingly into a state of extreme egocentricity. Circling round the concept “I”, we can generate painful backwards-looking feelings like guilt or regret. Or turn our tired thoughts to the always uncertain future, generating baseless fears. “Buddhism has a strong position on this type of mental activity: the self is a fiction, and that fiction is the source of all distress. Many of us now practise Buddhist-informed mindfulness to manage stress in the daytime I use mindfulness to deal with am wakings. “I bring my attention to my senses, specically the sound of my breath. When I notice thoughts arising, I gently bring my attention back to the sound of breathing . “Sometimes this meditation works. Sometimes it doesn’t. If I’m still caught in negative thinking after  or  minutes, I follow the advice from cognitive behavioural therapy, and get up, turn on dim light and read. “This action may seem mundane, but at am it is powerfully compassionate, and can help draw you out of your unproductive thinking. “One last tip: It’s important to convince yourselfthat you want to avoid catastrophic thinking. For good reasons not to worry, you can’t go past the Stoic philosophers. “Waking and worrying at am is very understandable and very human. But in my opinion, not a great habit to get into.” Comment MORE ON Mental healthInsomniaTherapySleep" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Brian Laundrie lookalike ambushed and held at gunpoint in hotel by US MarshalsSeverin Beckwith and his partner Anna Brettman were on a hiking trip along the Appalachian Trail in North Carolina when US Marshals burst down their door with guns and riot shieldsSeverin Beckwith was ambushed by US Marshals after he believes someone reported him as being Brian LaundrieByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | comments A man who looks similar to Brian Laundrie, the sole person authorities are looking for in the Gabby Petito case, said he was ambushed and held at gunpoint by US Marshals. Severin Beckwith and his partner Anna Brettman had their hotel room raided while they were sleeping during a trip near the Appalachian Trail in North Carolina. They were planning to hike from Georgia to Virginia and decided to stay at the Lodge at Fontana Village Resort to get some sleep. Severin says that before he could even unlock the door US Marshals burst into the room with guns drawn and holding up riot shields. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletterHe told the New Yorker : Next thing I see is a bunch of guys with riot shields with ‘US Marshals’ written on them. Handguns pointed at my face.”Severin, who was still in his underwear, was handcuffed and taken into the hotel hallway while investigators tried to confirm his identity.Gabby, , was reported missing in September after Laundrie, , ed from a cross-country road trip from New York to Oregon without her.Gabby was last seen leaving a hotel with Laundrie in Utah in late August. After a widespread search for her, the social media influenceraposs remains were found in a remote area in Wyoming, US, on September . Laundrie disappeared from his home in North Port on September  after telling his parents he was going for a hike. Law enforcement has been desperately looking for Laundrie as he is the only person of interest named in Gabbyaposs death. US Marshals let Severin go due to his lack of knuckle tattoos and personal ID papers.  One federal agent reportedly suggested he shave his beard to avoid further confusion during his hike along the Appalachian Trail. Severin believes someone alerted federal agents after mistaking him for Laundrie. He claims the marshals showed him a photo that a witness discreetly took, which showed him on his mobile phone. He said: They had a little side-by-side. It was Brian and then me on the phone calling to get the shuttle.  He was later released and given a free nightaposs stay at the lodge for their unique troubles. Gabby was last seen on August  when she apologized to restaurant staff after Laundrie argued with them. Several days later, Laundrie ed to Florida on September  alone while Gabby was left alone in a hotel in Utah. Her family reported her missing on September . Laundrie has refused to speak to the cops and was also reported missing on September . Gabbyaposs remains were found in Wyoming two days later on September  and her death was ruled a homicide. Police issued a warrant for Laundrieaposs arrest on September . title: hooters backtracks new uniform policy
story: Hooters backtracks on new unorm policy after staff hit out at ‘underwear’ shortsThe restaurant chain brought in a new dress code that featured revealing skimpy shorts that has "upset" some employees Image: TikTokByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Oct | commentsHooters has been forced to backtrack on its controversial new unorm policy after complaints from staff members that said it was “x-rated” and “disturbing”. The restaurant chain, known for the tight-fitting unorms worn by its female staff, has now said it will allow employees to “choose” which unorm they wish to wear.In a statement to Insider, a spokesperson for Hooters said: “As we continue to listen and update the image of the Hooters Girls, we are clarying that they have the option to choose from traditional unorms or the new ones.They can determine which style of shorts best fits their body style and personal image. It followed its previous decision to replace already-short shorts for new skin-tight, bikini-cut bottoms, which some of its staff compared to underwear.  A series of viral TikTok videos shared by Hooters staff show employees speaking out against the shorts while others have threatened to quit as a result of the unorm change. “Oh look, a wedgie!” Hooters employee and medical student Kristen Songer, , said as she revealed the new shorts. “This is why all the Hooters girls are upset — because this is not what I agreed to wear a year ago when I was hired.”  In another video, one person compared the two shorts with the caption: “Love my job but don’t love wearing undies to work.” Another TikTok user said: “Soooo Hooters got new panties. I mean shorts.” The unorm change did receive positive feedback from some staff, one who said she was obsessed with the shorts while another asked Am I the only Hootie that loves the new shorts    “I’ve been making way more money with the new shorts,” a third said. Hooters has repeatedly come under fire for promoting the objectication of women through mandatory barely-there unorms, as well as staff beauty pageants and girl calendars.  The bar and restaurant chain launched in  with a unique selling point serving staff made up entirely of attractive, young women wearing orange hotpants and tight tops. Hooters of America, the franchisor and operator of Hooters restaurants, operates more than  franchise locations across  states and  countries. The company’s spokesperson added that the shorts were “the result of a collaboration with Hooters Girls and have been worn for months in several Texas markets with overwhelmingly positive feedback”. They said that Hooters appreciates the feedback, both positive and negative, regarding a more accommodating and inclusive image policy on tattoos, jewelry, nails, hairstyles as well as new unorm options — to include new top styles, shorts, and the addition of socks. The company said it plans to continue to work with employees and give them opportunities for providing input at every stage including future clothing items and accessories. Weaposre excited to see a national trend toward self-expression and inclusivity that bodes well for our marketplace, the spokesperson continued. We work continuously with our Hooters Girls to refresh and update the image of our brand ambassadors and to empower them to feel their best while at work. story: My family played a cruel prank on my we to test her on our wedding dayA man took to Reddit to ask users whether he was in the wrong for telling his mum and aunts to leave his wedding after they pulled a prank on his we, leaving her distraughtThe women would tease any new woman that entered the family dynamic Image: GettyByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Oct | commentsA man was left horried after his family decided to play a nasty prank on his we on their wedding day. A -year-old groom kicked out a number of his female family members from his wedding after they turned up in white dresses.He took to Reddit to share his story, where he explained: I have a large family. Mostly aunts and female cousins aside from mum, stepmum, stepsister, and grandmother.I donapost know how to say this but all those women I mentioned above are into teasing and joking. Theyaposve formed a unitand theyaposd tease and roast every new woman that enters the family by marriage by setting up apostestsapos to seethey deserve to be part of the family. Or roast their looks and styles to the point of breaking confidence and self-esteem down. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Then after a few months of teasing, theyaposd announce that theyaposve finally welcomed them into the family. The newest member would join in on the teasing too which is crazy as my dad says. Sadly, the same happened to his we. When I first introduced my then-girlfriend now we, I made it clear that I didnapost want any of the women in the unit to come at her or harass her not even with a single word, he said.They went behind my back and roasted her looks and job and I discovered theyaposve been doing it on Facebook. I had them apologise one by one after they gave the aposweaposre just testing the water to seesheaposs capable to be part of the familyapos excuse.They didnapost want to apologise but once I said I wouldnapost invite any of the unit unless they apologise, including my mum, everyone immediately apologised and brought gts for my we. First of them was my stepmum and my sister-in-law. But as the couple made plans to get married, he learned that there was talk about the women in the family wanting to pull a prank on my we by wearing white and called it the aposultimate testapos to see how my we react.  My brother warned me so I announced thatany one of them showed up in white Iaposd have them kicked out including mum. They said this wasnapost true and theyaposd never do such a thing. But they showed up to my wedding one by one wearing white dresses and each and every one of them was told to leave after they tried giving excuses by either making scenes or getting the men involved. The senior women of the unit, who are mum and aunts, also showed up in white but refused to leave. I threatened to take harsher action and mum was p***ed telling me to step aside but I didnapost let her in. I had her leave while the men in the family were watching stunned, dad was on my side and supported me a lot. I felt absolutely awful because my wedding was being interrupted by them making scenes. My we was hurt beyond measure but the women in the family were pissed. My cousin blasted me on social media later saying I excluded all the women from the wedding because my we was so insecure she couldnapost handle another womanaposs presence at her wedding. I had an argument with them and mum berated me saying it was supposed to be a prank but I said they were taking it too far. Mum said I took it too far by kicking them out because they were trying to get a reaction from my we to seeshe was one of those aposbridezillasapos and were going to change soon as the prank was over but I ruined my own and entire wedding by reacting so aggressively. I stopped talking after she said I had to bring my we and apologise. I havenapost seen the lot of them in two weeks and theyaposve excluded me from everything. He concluded his post by asking users whether he was in the wrong for how he handled the situation but many people said he did the right thing by standing up for his we. One person said: Your family is toxic and I am so sad for your we that they would do that, but also so happy for her that she has a husband who will support her and have her back. Iaposm sorry your family tried to hijack your wedding for a power play, but you did the right thing, and your marriage will be stronger because of it. Another commented: A prank is only a prankeveryone ends up laughing. Otherwise, itaposs just bullying. story: Amateur scuba er finds -year-old Crusader sword  metres off coastShlomi Katzin made the discovery while scuba ing about  metres out to sea at the weekend. He alerted the Israel Antiquities Authority, which confirmed the sword belonged to a Crusader knightThe sword is believed to have belonged to a Crusader who sailed to the Holy Land almost a millennium ago Image: REUTERSByChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct | commentsAn amateur scuba er has found a -year-old Crusader sword off Israelaposs coast, the countryaposs Antiquities Authority has announced. Shlomi Katzin made the discovery while scuba ing about  metres out to sea at the weekend. He noticed several remains including pottery fragments, stone and metal anchors, as well as the blade. He decided to bring it up to the surface as he was worried the precious object might get covered by the sand. Mr Katzin then alerted the Israel Antiquities Authority , which confirmed the sword belonged to a Crusader knight. IAA’s Robbery Prevention Unit Inspector Nir Distelfeld said: The sword, which has been preserved in perfect condition, is a beautul and rare find and evidently belonged to a Crusader knight.  It was found encrusted with marine organisms but is apparently made of iron. It is exciting to encounter such a personal object, taking you  years back in time to a dferent era, with knights, armor and swords. The sword was buried at a shallow depth of about four or five metres in an area regularly frequented by ers, Mr Katzin said. It has a metre-long blade and a -centimeter hilt, archaeologists have explained.  Kobi Sharvit, head of the authority’s marine archaeology unit, said: The shape and, of course, the location leave no doubt that it is of Crusader provenance. We have only started now to carefully work on clearing away the sediment and then we’ll x-ray it and hopefully we’ll be able to work out whether it was manufactured locally or brought over by one of the Crusaders. We may even find on the hilt or blade some markings that will allow us to discover some clues as to the owner and which Crusader order he belonged to and which crusade he was on.  After handing over the sword, the scuba er received a certicate of appreciation for good citizenship, according to reports. The First Crusade was the first of a series of religious wars and took place from  to . Christian knights from Europe captured Jerusalem where they began massacring the cityaposs Muslim and Jewish population. They also established mini-kingdoms in the area, with some ruins still visible in Israel today. There is a possibility that the sword found by Mr Katzin on Saturday had fallen from a ship or was on a ship that was wrecked there. Mr Sharvit said it is rare to find artacts like the sword, but probably thanks to a recent storm the sand moved and now several objects from dferent periods are emerging. story: Dad captures moment st bear breaks into family home and sits on sons chairSean Reddy said a black bear entered his property through an open bedroom window earlier this month. He called his neighbour who came over with some bear sprayThe family was shocked to find a huge black bear standing up at a desk in a bedroom Image: Sean ReddyByPeter BarkerChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct | commentsA dad has captured the moment a -stone bear broke into his house and sat on his sonaposs gaming chair. Sean Reddy said a black bear entered his property through an open bedroom window on October . He said he was cleaning up his garden because a bear had made a mess after knocking over the bins the night before. But as he walked around his garden in Alberta, Canada, his two dogs suddenly became very agitated. Sean said he recognised the dogsapos behaviour as they displayed it before when there was a bear nearby. The dogs soon had the bear cornered near the garage, but Sean shouted at them to back off as the animal could have seriously injured them.  He said: The bear did not seem too fazed by my dogs and I was yelling at them to call them back so as not to get killed by the bear. I locked them [the dogs] in my shop and closed the door to leave the bear alone. The bear then made its way into the garage where it got its paws on dog food and some items in the freezer. Sean told his children, Ronan and Cormac, to stay inside and not go anywhere near the garage as the bear was there. The family watched the bear from their window and assumed that after finishing the food it would head back into the woods. However, just minutes later -year-old Cormac asked his dad what all the scratching he could hear coming from the other end of the house was. Ronan then shouted to his dad, saying the bear was now in the hallway. The dad said: I went in to see and sure enough there it was. I donapost remember what I said orI was yelling at the bear, but thataposs when he walked into Cormacaposs room.  Sean thought a window was open in the room so he shut the door and hoped that the bear would leave the same way it came in. He rushed outside to checkthe window really was open only to find that it was shut. He said: Now just realising that I had locked the bear in Cormacaposs room, I ran back into the house to see and went down the hallway to find out my son Liam had left his bedroom window wide open and thataposs where the bear had come in. Sean said the bear had climbed through Liamaposs room, across his bed, and then wandered through the house to Cormacaposs room. He added: I wasnapost sure what to do, thinking the bear was going to be p****d off at me for being locked in the room.  With Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Fish and Wildle officials unreachable, Sean was left to his own devices when it came to removing the bear from his sonaposs bedroom. He called his neighbour Chris who came over with some anti-bear spray. Sean said: We decided to get a bunch of furniture ready to block off the hallway, there is a bookshelf by Cormacaposs bedroom which I had pulled back thinking at leastI opened up the door and a mad bear was coming out I had a bookshelf between us. However, when he opened the bedroom door the bear did not show itself. Sean explained: I climbed over the small bookshelf to look in, and the bear was at the computer desk looking back at me asto say aposwhat do you want apos He added: Thataposs when I said to the guys here aposI have to take a picture because no one will believe me!apos The bear walked across the hallway back towards the bedroom and left shortly after Sean took the picture of it by his sonaposs gaming chair. The bear has not been seen since, but Sean says that bear sightings are not uncommon near the familyaposs home although normally they keep to the garden and the garage. story: Horric real-le Squid Game sees thousands of prisoners harvested for organs ALIVEWARNING: UPSETTING CONTENT. Tens of thousands of dissidents and political prisoners are reportedly harvested in China every year as part of a barbaric black market operation led by the Chinese governmentA Falun Gong follower displays torture methods they claim Chinese authorities used against their members in China Image: ReutersByAlex BellottiNews Features Writer:,  Oct | commentsCalled to a remote hillside on a hot summeraposs day, Dr Enver Tothi felt a chill down his spine as gunshots rang out across the fields. Walking his team over the summit, the medical expert was greeted by the sight of up to  men wearing prisonersapos unorms collapsed leless on the ground. Their heads had been blown off by military police who stood over twitching corpses - the job of Dr Tothi was to harvest fresh organs, which have become a valuable commodity on the Chinese black market. The horric scenes may sound eerily similarly to the side plot in Netflixaposs smash hit drama Squid Game, but the gruesome practice is all too real.Human rights groups in China claim the government is operating an organ-trafficking network that harvests as many as , dissidents and political prisoners every year.Hearts, kidneys, livers and even corneas are all removed on an industrial scale, campaigners say - while those involved have revealed grim secrets of witnessing the barbaric scenes first-hand. Organs aposharvestedapos like in Netflix hit Since its release last month, Squid Game has quickly become the most-viewed international show in Netflixaposs history. The creepy South Korean thriller sees desperate contestants battle it out in childhood-inspired games to win millions of pounds - the catch being thatthey fail, they die. Get the biggest news delivered to your inbox.for the Mirroraposs free newslettersWhile the far-fetched premise thankfully isnapost inspired by real le, a side plot sees workers for the aposgameapos dragging off injured participants to harvest their organs and sell them off. Just months before the showaposs release, UN human rights experts warned they were extremely alarmed by reports of alleged organ harvesting in real le. Minorities including followers of the religious movement Falun Gong, Uyghurs, Tibetans, Muslims and Christians are being targeted in detention in China, the reports claim. The UN experts say they have received credible information that detainees are being mysteriously subjected to blood tests and organ examinations such as ultrasound and x-rays - without consent. “Forced organ harvesting in China appears to be targeting specic ethnic, linguistic or religious minorities held in detention, often without being explained the reasons for arrest or given arrest warrants, at dferent locations,” they said. “We are deeply concerned by reports of discriminatory treatment of the prisoners or detainees based on their ethnicity and religion or belief. “According to the allegations received, the most common organs removed from the prisoners are reportedly hearts, kidneys, livers, corneas and, less commonly, parts of livers. This form of trafficking with a medical nature allegedly involves health sector professionals, including surgeons, anaesthetists and other medical specialists.”  China is facing a huge shortage of organs that can be used for transplants, but under controversial rules recipients can book surgeries for specic dates and locations. This doesnapost happen in other countriesapos systems, as surgeons cannot predict when a potential donor will die. Under Chinaaposs rules, the donoraposs organs will be sent to the most urgent patient on a waiting list who is within travelling distance. This has allowed the country to establish a horric aposkill to orderapos system, but despite widespread condemnation, Beijing has been able to cover it up by under-reporting transplant figures to the World Health Organisation.A recent statistical analysis of Chinaaposs current organ transplant system showed the numbers China has been putting out have been falsied, Susie Hughes, executive director of The International Coalition to End Transplant Abuse in China, told Daily Mail Australia.When you examine hospital revenues, bed utilisation rates and the number of surgical teams from the official Chinese data... the figure is more likely to be between , to , transplants per year. aposI became a robot... you carry out what you are programmed toapos China has persecuted a number of minority groups over the years, with thousands of Falun Gong detained as religious prisoners around the turn of the century. In , human rights lawyers began campaigning on the issue of organ harvesting, but  years later, little has been done to curb the sickening practice.  While the Falun Gong were once the target of the authorities, following its effective dissolution as a movement the Uighur - an ethnic group of Muslims now largely situated in the north-west of China - became the new scapegoat.Last year, the China Tribunal published a landmark  page report after  months of investigation into organ harvesting in the country. Dr Tothi - who now works as a London Uber driver - contributed to the enquiry, having been forced to remove a prisoners organs while working as a doctor in .I became a robot, the father-of-three told MirrorOnline. You carry out what you are programmed to do. When I cut through there was bleeding, which means the heart was still beating. I understood why. This man was shot to the right chest. They knocked him out but did not let him die immediately so I had time to remove the organs.  It was an easy and quick operation which took  to  minutes. Even less because it’s a destructive operation. The chief surgeon put the organs in a box and said aposnow you take your team back to hospital, and today nothing happenedapos. When Dr Tothi was made to carry out the brutal surgery, the Chinese Communist Party was concerned with the Falun Gong - a religious group that top brass considered to be a grave threat to their authority. The identity of the man he was forced to operate on, without anesthetic, remains a mystery to him. Prisoner x-rayed at horric concentration camp Tens of thousands of Falun Gong prisoners of conscience are thought to have been killed so that their organs could be sold in the lucrative black market.Among the lucky survivors was Jenner Zeng, who was saved from having her innards plundered by a chance admission to a prison guard. For  hours a day the mum-of-one was forced to stand in the sun and recite regulations at a prison camp in Beijing until she fainted, at which point a guard would shock her awake with an electric batton. Itaposs very sad, because we failed to stop them when they did this to Falun Gong, Ms Zeng toldof the state-run programme of forced organ harvesting. The western world funded this persecution by investing in China. Thenow has the power to expand this mass murder to Uighur and the people of Hong Kong. During her time in the camp Ms Zeng was taken to a medical facility where she had her eyes tested and her organs touched. She explained to the doctor that she had been infected with hepatitis C during a blood transfusion after giving birth, but had been cured of it in the process of practising Falun Gong. A month later she and several thousand inmates were taken in shackles in large buses with their windows blacked out to a hospital where they were x-rayed. At a smaller clinic back at the camp their blood was taken without explanation. It was only after her release that Ms Zeng learned that the authorities had been removing the organs of prisoners to be sold to wealthy and powerful people, from China and from overseas. Only at that stage, I realised what a narrow escape I had, she explained.  If I had not told the doctor I had had hepatitis C, I could have become a victim as well. From my first dayI had a strange feeling. Is this real  Have I been sent to the concentration camps in the history books  Could this be happening in the st century  We read about it in the history books but it doesnapost happen anymore. I had been transferred to the Nazi concentration camps. That kind of feeling haunted me for a long time. aposMy name is the butcher... itaposs like slaughtering pigsapos Also included in the  report is a transcript of a telephone call between an investigator and Zhu Jiabin, who admits to murdering and harvesting the organs of Gao Yixi in . Asked about the harvesting, Jiabin says: Sold them!’ After slaughtering and opening up the belly, you just carve out the organs and sell them. I only know to sell organs for money after organ harvesting. That is my principle... If you had guts to stand in front of me now I would live organ harvest you... My name is ‘the butcher’... I am called the butcher specialising in live organ harvesting... Itaposs nothing, just like slaughtering pigs. You come over to shave their hair first and then split open the belly. I would carve out whatever I need. After scooping the organs out, I would sell them.Last year, a group of doctors were found to have harvested the organs of car crash victims and then sold them for cash.Six people, including four doctors, were jailed in China having been caught up in the countryaposs thriving organ black market. It followed growing reports that the country was executing Muslim prisoners and taking their organs to treat patients dying of Covid-. Concerns were raised after Beijing boasted about a successful double transplant operation on a patient given just days to live.
